commit_list.message:
Merge branch 'jvoegele-dialyzer-fixes'

Dialyzer fixes:
* `Diplomat.Key.parent` field was using the wrong type (`Diplomat.Entity.t`
  instead of `Diplomat.Key.t`)
* Several fields on `Diplomat.Key` are optional and need type specs that
  allow for `nil`.
* Some type specs were using `%{}` to represent a map type, but this
  literally means an empty map so they were replaced with the type
  `map()`.
* Replaced a few instances of pattern matching on `%{}` with `when is_map(...)`.

commit_list.message:
Add a new option to Entity.new to sanitize property keys

Datastore uses the dot character (`.`) as it's path separator for
referencing nested entities, so it's not allowed in a property name. By
default, Diplomat will not change property names, but if you pass the
new option :santize_keys to Entity.new, it will replace illegal
characters with an underscore (or a string you pass in)
commit_list.repo_description: Elixir library for interacting with Google's Cloud Datastore

without the explicit scope we've asked for.

commit_list.message:
cut down on the chattiness of the flow control communication

There's a :bug: in this code as we're not properly tracking the flow
control for the connection AND the stream separately (we're assuming
that they are the same, which will cause an error when you try to update
a frame's flow control window before it's exhausted, thus causing the
window to go above the max possible value (if we send the max possible
value as the increment))

commit_list.message:
set the INITIAL_WINDOW_SIZE to the max (2^31-1)

for some reason, when the value isn't the max, the server will stop
sending data, even if we keep updating the flow window with the same
value of bytes that we received. I :suspect: there's some :bug: in the way
that I'm calculating the size of the payloads (maybe, for instance, the
flow control window includes the headers when counting how many bytes
have been sent?)

start extracting Frame parsing into type-specific modules

structs) that will handle parsing of headers (River.Frame.Headers) and
data (River.Frame.Data) frames. Frame specific fields and flags should
be easier to handle with this approach

commit_list.message:
More rearranging. We'll get this all figured out eventually

The supervision tree now looks something like this:

River.Supervisor
  └── River.ConnectionSupervisor
  |     ├── River.Connection<pid>
  |	├── River.Connection<pid>
  |	└── ...
  └── River.StreamSupervisor
        ├── River.Stream<pid>
	├── River.Stream<pid>
	└── ...

we have successfully completed our first http/2 request

There's still plenty left to do here, of course, and there are lots of
bugs even in this simple implementation:

* frames that span multiple packets won't work right now
* we have absolutely no idea how to handle multiple streams
* so many other things....

commit_list.message:
River now requires Elixir v1.5+

This is because we're using the dynamic supervision support of the
:simple_one_for_one strategy, to which we pass child specs generated via
Supervisor.child_spec/2. We could probably route around this by
generating the child specs directly, though... hrm

commit_list.message:
mysql utf8mb4 encoding supports a max index length of 767 bytes

This means that a string column that will have an index has two options:
  * limit the max length of the column to 191 chars (191 * 4 = 764)
  * use a prefix index (index only the first part of the string),
    and ensure it's less than the max
